subject: Re: [junit] Re: A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: I think that if you used your own custom version of assertThat, you could make some very nice logs.  Good luck, David Saff
messageBody:
I think that if you used your own custom version of assertThat, you
could make some very nice logs. Good luck,

David Saff

On Tue, Mar 10, 2009 at 7:38 PM, rsgmxw <markwilhelm@...> wrote:
> One thing about the "logging of assertions" is reporting on the Actual/Observed results. I work at a company that makes Medical Devices. The FDA, as we're told by QA, requires the deposition of all tests. So even Pass'ing tests must have their actual results reported on. We do this currently with manual/human tests.
>
> If the report could say something like:
> Test ID Status Expected        Actual
> 123       Pass  Smith           Smith
> 456       Pass  Value > 10      12
> 789       Fail  Value = "abc"   xyz
> ...
>
> This report would be stored (for many years) for audit purposes.
>
> Now being a newbie, maybe there is a way to do this I don't know about - but very useful.
>
> Mark
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "toalexsmail" <toalexsmail@...> wrote:
>>
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Wenner <robert.wenner@> wrote:
>> >
>> > On Monday 09 June 2008 21:18, Cédric Beust  wrote:
>> > > > If I have to go through umpteen thousand lines of log, I may as well
>> > > > test everything manually.
>> > >
>> > > Nobody says you have to, but the fact that your tests pass doesn't
>> > > guarantee that you are testing what you think you are testing.
>> >
>> > Well. If the log is important, I have to go through it, or I miss
>> > something important. If it is not important (and I don't have to go
>> > through it) I can skip it altogether. So what do you mean when you
>> say I
>> > don't have to go through it?
>> >
>>
>> I have read carefully all the posts so far and I tend to agree with
>> Robert. I am wonder whether I miss something important too.
>> I want to be clear, so I will take one step backward. What is the MAIN
>> purpose of JUnit? The answer is to be able to write AUTOMATIC unit
>> test. Unit test should be written is the correct way, that is
>> correctly design. This has nothing to do with logging. Making unit
>> test AUTOMATIC contradict using logging.
>>
>> <you can skip the this paragraph>
>> I want to step aside for a while. Let assume that you're not using
>> JUnit at all and write small main function to test. I don't want to
>> counter why you shouldn't do this, let focus on what tools you do use
>> in this approach. In the most cases you will add System.out both to
>> the code and to the main. If you're using C++, for instance, you will
>> use preprocessor to switch on or off these output to the console. More
>> advance option will be to use logging mechanism and to change it
>> configuration depends on the environment your program run (that is to
>> turn on many of your log statement only in development). Everything is
>> great until your program is actually fails. Again, from the experience
>> it is almost always the case that existing System.outs are not enough,
>> that you need more information or you should add some more output
>> early in the code. So, in this point you have to option to run your
>> program AGAIN with debugger or to add more System.outs and to run it
>> as is. In both cases it can be the case that you should rerun your
>> program again (if you use debugger you could simply not pointed out
>> when some data changed and in the System.out case you can figure out
>> that you need more System.outs).
>>
>> From the paragraph above one should conclude that when one write unit
>> test there is 2 different phases. First is to write them down in the
>> hope that everything will be ok (it doesn't mean, that you design
>> should be poor or you shouldn't supply appropriate messages to assert
>> statements etc) and the second phase is to rerun your test if your
>> test fails. Lets see how logging will help you.
>>
>> In the first phase I see the only purpose using logs is for 'sanity
>> check' that is to ensure that you actually test what your think is you
>> test. If you want to make something more than just 'sanity check' you
>> should write unit test to your unit test, that is pretty silly.
>> Moreover, you need to make such 'sanity check' only when you actually
>> write this test.  For this purpose logging is appropriate approach, IMHO.
>>
>> In the second phase, when you rerun your unit test when it fails, you
>> should consider to add more assert statement and more clearly
>> diagnostic messages first. When you done and you don't see how to
>> improve the design (recall I consider that design is correct) you can
>> add log statement manually. But in this case they will not be part of
>> new mechanism, because no more asserts will be added. So this new
>> feature will not be in use!
>>
>> Using logging in the assert statement ONLY for 'sanity check' is
>> overkill, I think. As for me I make such 'sanity check' in the
>> following way. First of all, I use log4j MANUALLY that is as addition
>> to JUnit asserts. They don't duplicate what asserts does they supply
>> additional information, such as what assertion was already done. In
>> this case when assertion will fail afterwards I can look on the log to
>> see in what part of unit test it happened and what tests passed. I go
>> even further and use JDK 1.4 assert statement to document
>> precondition, postcondition and invariants both in the code and in the
>> unit test.
>>
>> The bottom line is that I see the sense using logs as a COMPLETION to
>> the JUnit and only for 'sanity check'. This use is not duplicates
>> JUnit assert statements and could be written manually.
>>
